solution.text: \(3x^2\) – Monomial. Because this expression has only one term
\(17x + 6\) – Binomial. Even though it only has one variable, it has two terms.
\(9y + x\) – Binomial. Because this expression has two terms.
\(8\) – Monomial. Even though it doesn’t have any variables this expression has only one term and thus is a monomial.
\(9xy\) – Monomial. Even though it has two variables, they are both part of a single term.
\(7z\) – Monomial. Because this expression only has one term.
\(15x +2\) – Binomial. Because this expression has two terms.
\(a + b\) – Binomial. Because this expression has two terms.
\(a + b + c\) – Trinomial. Because this expression has three terms.
\(13xy + xy + 16\) – Binomial. Because it can be simplified to two terms \(14xy + 16\).
\(3xyz – 6\) – Binomial. Because this expression has two terms.
\(19x + 17y\) – Binomial. Because this expression has two terms.
\(2z^2 - 8y^2\) – Binomial. Because this expression has two terms.

content.text: Classify the following as monomials, binomials and trinomials

hint.text: Monomials have ONE TERM (e.g. \(3x\)). Binomials have TWO TERMS (e.g. \(3x + 2\)). Trinomials have THREE TERMS (e.g. \(3x + 2 + 2y\))

solution.text:
Income = \(429x\)
Constant expense \(= 95\)
Variable expense \(= 33y\)
Therefore, Earnings \(= 429x – 95 – 33y\)

content.text: An electrician earns Rs.429 per hour and spends Rs.95 a day on petrol. He also buys electric wire at Rs.33 per metre. Last Monday, he worked for x hours and purchased y metres of wire. What algebraic expression represents his earnings for that day?

hint.text: Identify the variables in the problem (x and y) and then try and form an equation to calculate income. For instance, if I earn Rs.40 per hour and work 8 hours on Monday, then my income on Monday was \(40 \times 8\)

solution.text:
Your income = \(60x\)
Your friend’s income = \(20y\)
Required money for scooter = \(24000\)
Therefore \(24000 = 60x + 20y\)

content.text: You and your friend decide to get a part time job to earn some money to buy a scooter worth Rs.24000. The job you get pays you Rs.60 per hour and the job your friend gets pays him Rs.20 per hour. Assuming you work for x hours and your friend works for y hours, what algebraic expression describes the number of hours you and your friend need to work for to purchase the scooter.

solution.text:
Now, your friend says he will only work half the number of hours you will.So if you work x hours and he works y hours then \(y = \frac{x}{2}\)
Substituting the value of y into the equation obtained in part 1, we get:
\(24000 = 60x + 20\frac x2\)
\(\Rightarrow 24000 = x(60+ \frac{20}{2})\)
\(\Rightarrow x = \frac{24000}{60+ \frac{20}{2}}\)
\(\Rightarrow x = 342.86\)

content.text:
Use the information given in the first part.
Your friend says he will only work half the amount of time that you work. Using this information, how many hours will you have to work before you both have enough money to purchase the scooter?

hint.text: Identify the variables in the problem (x and y) and then try and form an equation to calculate income. For instance, if I earn Rs.40 per hour and work 8 hours on Monday, then my income on Monday was \(40 \times 8\)

solution.text:
\(13x\). Correct. The only variable is x
\(13x+2\). Correct. The only variable is x
\(13y + x\). Incorrect. There are two variables here: x and y
\(13t\). Correct. The only variable is t
\(13xy\). Incorrect. There are two variables here: x and y
\(13z\). Correct. The only variable is z
\(13p^2 + 5\). Correct. The only variable is p
\(13q^3\). Correct. The only variable is q

content.text: Which of the following expressions have only one variable?

hint.text: Look at the expressions and make a list of number of variables and constants. Then count the number of distinct variables.

solution.text:
\((ab – bc) – (bc – ca) + (ca – ab)\)
\(= ab – bc – bc + ca + ca – ab\)
\(= ab – ab – bc – bc + ac + ac\)
\(= 2ac – 2bc\)

hint.text:
Open the brackets and group the like terms. Then add or subtract.
\(For example: (a-b) – (2a – 3b)\)
\(= a – 2a – b – (-3b)\)
\(= a – 2a – b + 3b\)
\(= -a + 2b\)

solution.text:
Let the number be represented by abcd (for instance if the number was 3456 then a = 3, b = 4, c = 5 and d = 6)
Given
d = 2a
b = c-a
d = c-1
a < 6 and is odd so a = 1,3,5 but d=2a and d can’t be equal to 10, therefore a = 1,3
Let’s assume a = 1
Then d = 2a = 2, c = d+1 = 3 and b = c-a = 2
Thus the number would be 1232. But it is given that no two digits are the same, therefore a = 3.
Then d = 2a = 6, c = d+1 = 7 and b = c-a = 4
Thus the number is 3746

content.text: I am a four digit number with no two digits the same. My ones digit is twice my thousands digit and my thousands digit is one less than my tens digit. My hundreds digit is the sum of my tens digit and my thousands digit. My thousands digit is an odd number less than 6. What number am I?

solution.text:
\((7x-14y)(7x-14y)\)
\(= (7x – 14y)^2\)
Using identity \((a-b)^2 = a^2 + b^2 – 2ab\)
Where \(a = 7x\) and \(b = 14y\)
\(= 49x^2 + 196y^2 – 196xy\)

hint.text:
Consider the expressions you’re trying to multiply. Break one expression into its separate terms and multiply each term with the second expression. Then add or subtract the terms to simplify.
For example:
\((x+2y)(2x-3y)\)
\(= x(2x – 3y) + 2y(2x-3y)\) [Here x+2y is broken into its two terms]
\(= 2x^2 – 3xy + 4xy – 6y^2\)
\(= 2x^2 + xy – 6y^2\)
